settings.text: Travelling can wreak havoc on our body, mind and skin. If you're planning on getting away, be sure to read Chinti & Parker's guide to on the road skincare.

settings.grid-content:
1. A guide to travel skincare

Whilst the anticipation and destination of a holiday is glorious, there’s no getting away from the fact that travelling - whether it’s by air, train or road - isn’t easy on our body, mind or skin. But you don’t have to arrive at your destination feeling sluggish and dehydrated. Here’s how to land at point B feeling, and looking, completely refreshed

2. How to travel with your skincare

Due to airport restrictions, carrying liquids in your hand luggage - including skincare products - is limited to 100ml. Luckily, there is an abundance of travel kits on the market, as well as your most loved products in miniature form. Simply pop these into a clear sealed bag inside your hand luggage and you’re ready to fly, or decant your favourites into appropriate containers.

If you have a check-in bag, and enough space, bring along your whole routine. Travelling can impact your skin in a number of ways, so it’s best to stick with a known skincare routine, even when on a trip.

settings.text:
3. What to eat before a flight

Taking care of yourself doesn’t start when you arrive at your destination. Even something as simple as the journey itself can wreak havoc on your body and skin. If you’re travelling by plane, it’s especially important to plan in advance.

You may start your day with a latte, or treat yourself to the traditional airport lounge wine at the start of your vacation, but both caffeine and alcohol can seriously disrupt your quality of sleep. Try to avoid them where possible.

The day before you board, avoid “heavy” foods, fatty or spicy meals as these can make your journey uncomfortable. Eat light meals made up of complex carbohydrates and protein to feel fuller for longer and make you less likely to snack on nutrient-deficient foods.

Fuelling up before take off, or taking your own healthy snacks on board, can help you opt out of the in-flight meals and salty, processed snacks. Eating the foods we’ve mentioned can help avoid “jet bloat”.

What does this have to do with your skin? We all know that our skin can often reflect how we feel on the inside. Flying is tough on your skin to begin with, but nourishing yourself from within can make all the difference when you land.

settings.grid-content:
4. Prepare your skin for flying

Do what you can to ensure that your skin is in tip-top condition before setting foot in the airport. A few days before you travel, give yourself an at-home facial or a face mask at the very least. Better yet, book a professional facial to thoroughly cleanse your pores and give your skin a new lease of life.

Before you travel, use a gentle cleanser and follow with products that will hydrate your skin, such as a toner and serum. Seal it all in with a rich moisturiser. Don’t forget your SPF.

settings.grid-content:
5. In-flight skincare

There’s no reason to let things slip when you’re 34,000 feet in the air. Maintain good skincare practices in-flight and ditch the wipes, however tempting they may be for a quick refresh, and instead, opt for a nourishing face oil. Lack of fresh air and low humidity in the cabin can leave your skin feeling dry, and a face oil - such as jojoba or frankincense - can give your face and neck some much needed rehydration.

If you’re in the air overnight, plan ahead and decant your usual products into containers smaller than 100ml, or invest in travel size duplicates. Despite the cramped conditions, try to follow your usual routine in the bathroom before you settle in for even a modicum of sleep. Try using a rich moisturiser before your flight, or pop a travel size in your hand luggage to replenish your skin mid-flight.

6. How flying affects your skin

Flying, and travelling in general, can dehydrate us quickly, as we’re often too busy to stop and drink water. For flights, the limited liquid allowance can make things tricky, but try increasing your pre-flight water intake for a head start. Once you’re in the air, regularly ask for bottles of water and remember that warm liquids, such as herbal tea and hot water with lemon, also count. Aeroplanes can get cold, so use this as a chance to warm from the inside out.

7. Try to prioritise sleep

Whether it’s a long-haul flight or an hour or two in the car, sleep is a great tool for getting through difficult journeys. Your body and skin will feel the benefits of any shut-eye you manage to get; here’s how to get the most rest.

Part of getting any rest on a flight, or indeed any mode of transport, relies heavily on what we dress in. Opt for comfort over style, although a combination of our cashmere jumpers and track pants are a perfect blend of both. Warm and cosy clothing will keep you comfortable. Pack a small neck pillow in your hand luggage, as well as noise-blocking headphones and an eye mask. If you’re struggling to relax, try a meditation app, such as Calm or Headspace.

8. Look after your skin post-flight

Once you arrive at your destination, find somewhere you can reset your skin. If you are able, go through a slimmed-down skincare routine, cutting down to the basics and focusing on cleansing to remove dirt and oil, and hydrating to replace lost moisture. Even a quick spritz with a face mist and a slather of moisturiser will make you feel ten times better. Finish off with caffeine eye cream to help with puffiness.

9. Build a travel-friendly skincare routine

Whilst away, continue to follow your regular skincare routine. This is not the time to trial new products as your reaction to them won’t be known until it’s too late. When you’re already possibly dealing with hotter temperatures and unusual water (yes, it can make a difference), your skin will take solace in familiar products.

settings.text:
10. Why SPF is your BFF

Whether you’re jetting off to soaring temperatures or staying relatively local, don’t forget to apply SPF daily. Yes, even if there are clouds in the sky. Opt for a light and non-greasy SPF for daily application. If you’re spending time on the beach or by the pool in full sun, be sure to apply a minimum of factor 30 SPF regularly throughout the day.
